Uses of Package
de.stock.level

  • Packages that use de.stock.level 
    Package Description
    de.stock.action  
    de.stock.level  
  • Classes in de.stock.level used by de.stock.action 
    Class and Description
    ILevel
    A level, which is part of a LevelPack, consists of several parts:

    - The level stage
      The player starts at the first level stage and if this level stage is passed he gets in the next stage if available.
      He chooses one level pack at the beginning of a level stage.
      If a level is of type normal or award level is indicated through the level stage, see Settings_Level

    - The successor
      The next level(s) in a level pack
      A level pack doesn't need to follow a linear order, it can has branches, too.
      If the method getSuccessor() returns null the level pack is over

    - The events
      A level may have specific events, which are removed (but not stopped if running) from event observer if a level is passed and added if it gets started

    - The tradeables
      A level may have specific tradeables, which are removed from tradeable handler if a level is passed and added if it gets started

    - The goal
      The goal to reach to get in the next level

    - The prize
      The prize the player gets if he passes the level (if available)

    - The award
      The award the player gets if he passes the level (if available)

    A LevelPack development guide can be found at the LevelPackLoader
    ILevelPack
    The level system knows two types of level packs:

    - The normal level packs which are grouped in level stages
      Only one of these can run at the same time!
      (Level stage 1 and above)

    - The award level packs
      Multiple of these can run at the same time!
      (Level stage 0)

    A level pack - a packet of several levels - which has a name and a description.

    It may has tradeables which are available and events which can occur over the whole playtime of the level pack.
    (Every level in a level pack may have specific tradeables or events, too!)

    The player can choose from these packs at the beginning of the game and if a level stage is passed, too.

    An example is the (not so serious) level pack "Lemonade" with the following levels:

      1.

      1.
    LevelPackHandler
    The level pack handler holds all level packs in their specific level stage (See LevelPack and Settings_Level)
    and is the single point of contact for the ActionObserver if a level pack of a level stage
    is needed through the method LevelPackHandler.chooseLevelPack(Integer)
